    A Series of Novel Terpyridine-Skeleton Molecule Derivants Inhibit Tumor Growth and Metastasis by Targeting Topoisomerases

    • Han-Byeol Kwon†
      • , 
    • Chanmi Park†
      • , 
    • Kyung-Hwa Jeon†
      • , 
    • Eunyoung Lee†
      • , 
    • So-Eun Park†
      • , 
    • Kyu-Yeon Jun†
      • , 
    • Tara Man Kadayat‡
      • , 
    • Pritam Thapa‡
      • , 
    • Radha Karki‡
      • , 
    • Younghwa Na§
      • , 
    • Mi Sun Park∥
      • , 
    • Seung Bae Rho∥
      • , 
    • Eung-Seok Lee*‡
      • , and 
    • Youngjoo Kwon*†

    § College of Pharmacy, Cha University, Pochon 487-010, Republic of Korea

    SUBJECTS:

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    A series of novel terpyridine-skeleton molecules containing conformational rigidity, 14 containing benzo[4,5]furo[3,2-b]pyridine core and 15 comprising chromeno[4,3-b]pyridine core, were synthesized, and their biological activities were evaluated. 3-(4-Phenylbenzo[4,5]furo[3,2-b]pyridin-2-yl)phenol (8) was determined to be a nonintercalative topo I and II dual catalytic inhibitor and 3-(4-phenylchromeno[4,3-b]pyridine-2-yl)phenol (22) was determined to be a nonintercalative topo IIα specific catalytic inhibitor by various assays. These two catalytic inhibitors induced apoptosis in addition to G1 arrest in T47D human breast cancer cells with much less DNA toxicity than etoposide. Compounds 8 and 22 significantly inhibited tumor growth in HCT15 subcutaneously implanted xenografted mice. The modification of compounds 8 and 22 with the introduction of a methoxy instead of a hydroxy group enhanced endogenous topo inhibitory activity, metabolic stability in diverse types of liver microsomes and improved pharmacokinetic parameters in rat plasma such as augmentation of bioavailability (41.3% and 33.2% for 2-(3-methoxyphenyl)-4-phenylbenzofuro[3,2-b]pyridine (8-M) and 3-(4-phenylchromeno[4,3-b]pyridine-2-yl)methoxybenzene (22-M), respectively).

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Human topoisomerases (topos), which release DNA topological problems, unavoidably caused during DNA transcription, replication, recombination, and segregation of two identical copies of genomes in two daughter cells following replication, can be grouped into two types according to the number of strands cleavage in one round of action.(1-4) Topoisomerase type I (topo I) cleaves one strand of a DNA double helix to be relaxed and then rejoined. Topoisomerase type II (topo II) cleaves both strands of one DNA duplex to make another noncleaved duplex pass through a transient, topo II-mediated break and then followed by reannealing the cleaved strands. Topo II is distinct from topo I in that topo II acts as a homodimer, requiring Mg (II) and ATP hydrolysis for enzyme turnover and rapid kinetics; this enables it to cut both DNA strands simultaneously. In addition, topo II is the only enzyme available to disentangle the topological problems in chromosomes, which must occur during DNA replication, and to decatenate the replicated chromosomes by introducing transient double strand breaks.(5) Human topo II is categorized into two subclasses, namely, topo IIα and topo IIβ. Topo IIβ was discovered relatively recently compared to other topo enzymes.(6) Topo IIβ shares similar mechanism of action and domains with topo IIα. Topo IIα is a cell cycle dependent enzyme; it peaks during G2/M phase and decreases at the end of mitosis. The overexpression of topo IIα is only observed in proliferating cells, but the expression of topo IIβ is not changed during the cell cycle. Therefore, topo IIα is a more important factor for cell proliferation than topo IIβ.(7, 8) By these reasons, many researchers in medicinal chemistry recently started to develop topo IIα-specific inhibitors as anticancer reagents.(9-12)
    We have been studying to develop topo I- and/or topo IIα-targeting anticancer agents by synthesis of various flexible terpyridine derivatives (compound A) (Figure 1)(13) because derivatives of terthiophene, bioisostere of terpyridine, showed protein kinase C inhibitory activity and cytotoxicity against several human cancer cell lines.(14) The bioisosteric modification of flexible terpyridine possessing phenyl, thienyl, furyl, pyridyl, and/or hydroxy phenyl instead of 2, 4, and/or 6 position of pyridine moieties in terpyridine backbone generally resulted in increased topo I and/or topo IIα inhibitory activities as well as cytotoxicity against several cancer cell lines (compounds A-1, A-2). From previous results we found that selective inhibition to topo IIα against topo I increased according to increased quantity of hydroxyl group on phenyl moiety (compound A-1).(13d, 13e, 13g) We further investigated terpyridine-skeleton molecules containing conformational rigidity such as analogues of 2,4,6-trisubstituted pyridine containing 5,6-dihydrobenzo[h]quinolone (compound B), 5,6-dihydro[1,10]phenanthroline, 5,6-dihydrothieno[2,3-h]quinolone (compound D), 5H-chromeno[4,3-b]pyridines (compound E), and benzofuro[3,2-b]pyridine (compound F) which all have three fused ring and two nonfused rotatable rings (Figure 1).(15) The introduction of conformational rigidity with cyclization on topo I- and/or IIα-targeting compounds is very likely to induce compounds to fit more efficiently into the active site of enzymes or to work as an intercalator in the enzyme–DNA complex.(16) Also rigid structures are commonly considered to have little conformational entropy compared to flexible structures and can be more efficiently fitted into the active site of a receptor. The analogues of 2,4,6-trisubstituted pyridine containing 5,6-dihydrobenzo[h]quinolone (compound B) showed mild cytotoxicity against tested cancer cell lines. Among these analogues, compounds possessing 2-thienyl at the 2-position of central pyridine with combination of 2-furyl and 3-furyl had considerable topo I inhibitory activity but no activity against topo IIα.(15a) The analogues of 2,4-diarylchromenopyridines (compound E) containing 2-furyl or 2-thienyl at 2- or 4-position of central pyridine enhanced topo I or IIα inhibitory activity and cytotoxicity compared to 2,4,6-trisubstituted pyridine containing 5,6-dihydrobenzo[h]quinolone analogues (compound B).(15b) Both 5,6-dihydro[1,10]phenanthroline (compound C) and 5,6-dihydrothieno[2,3-h]quinolone analogues (compound D) did not show significant topo I and topo IIα inhibitory activities as well as cytotoxicity against several human cancer cell lines with a few exceptions.(15c, 15d) Benzofuro[3,2-b]pyridine analogues (compound F) with 2-furyl and/or 2-thienyl at 2 or 4 position of pyridine moiety displayed significant topo IIα inhibitory activities.(15f) Various chromene-moiety-containing compounds have been of interest as anticancer agents that block tubulin polymerization,(17) bind into the active sites of farnesyltransferase and arginine methyltransferase,(18) bind into estrogen receptor beta,(19) and have more diverse biological activities.(20) A series of compounds possessing a benzofuropyridine moiety were reported to have antinociceptive activity via binding to opioid receptors.(21) On the basis of these reported biological activities and previous results from our study on structure–activity relationship (SAR) for compounds containing chromenes, chromenopyridines, and benzofuropyridines, we synthesized, in this study, 29 rigid analogues of 2,4,6-trisubstituted pyridine containing chromenopyridine or benzofuropyridine moiety and evaluated their topo I and IIα inhibitory activities, cytotoxicity, and SAR. Furthermore, chromenopyridines and benzofuropyridines are the novel moieties only discovered in our research group shown to inhibit topo I and IIα activities and to exhibit cytotoxicity against several human cancer cell lines. In connection with a previous study for the development of novel antitumor agents bearing improved biological activities we introduced various functional groups in the chromenopyridine and benzofuropyridine moieties. Introduction of chloride in a substituted aryl group enhanced inhibition of topo I and IIα activities as well as cytotoxicity against several human cancer cell lines.(13b, 13f) Introduction of hydroxyl functionality on phenyl groups in the chromenopyridine and benzofuropyridine moieties also enhanced inhibition of topo I and IIα activities and cytotoxicity. In addition, we observed that increasing the number of hydroxyl group on phenyl ring increased topo IIα inhibitory activities and selectivity for topo IIα.(13d, 13e, 13g) On the basis of the results, we designed chromenopyridines and benzofuropyridines bearing thienyl, furyl, phenyl, chlorofuryl, and hydroxyphenyl moieties as shown in Figure 2. Among synthesized compounds listed in Figure 3, 3-(4-phenylbenzo[4,5]furo[3,2-b]pyridin-2-yl)phenol (8) and 3-(4-phenylchromeno[4,3-b]pyridine-2-yl)phenol (22) were selected for further study to determine the mode of action and to evaluate in vitro and in vivo antitumor efficacy. We also designed compounds 2-(3-methoxyphenyl)-4-phenylbenzofuro[3,2-b]pyridine (8-M) and 3-(4-phenylchromeno[4,3-b]pyridine-2-yl)-methoxybenzene (22-M) as prodrugs of compounds 8 and 22, respectively, to improve metabolic stability and pharmacokinetic parameters.

    Chemistry

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    3-Coumaranopyridine derivatives and 4-chromanopyridine derivatives were synthesized in three steps on the basis of previously reported methods(15b, 22) as shown in Scheme 1. At first, seven pyridinium iodide salts II (R1 = a–g) were synthesized in 45.3–98.3% yield by refluxing seven different aryl methyl ketones I (R1 = a–g) with iodine and pyridine for 3 h. In parallel, 3-coumaranone (Scheme 1A) intermediates IV (R2 = f–i) and 4-chromanone (Scheme 1B) intermediates V (R2 = f–i) were prepared on the basis of the Claisen–Schmidt condensation reaction.(15b) Four different aryl aldehydes III (R2 = f–i) reacted with 3-coumaranone or 4-chromanone in the presence of Al2O3 or NaOH to give 67.9–94.2% of IV (R2 = f–i) and 63.0–94.8% of V (R2 = f–i), respectively. By treatment of pyridinium iodide salts II (R1 = a–g) with intermediates IV (R2 = f–i) or V (R2 = f–i), using modified Kröhnke synthesis,(22) compounds VI (R1 = a–g, R2 = f–i) and VII (R1 = a–g, R2 = f–i) were synthesized with a yield of 20.9–58.6%. Structures of synthesized compounds are shown in Figure 3, and the yields, purities, and melting points of the synthesized compounds are listed in Table S1.

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Topo Inhibitory Effects of Synthesized Compounds on Recombinant Topo I and IIα

    As noted previously, the 2,4-diphenyl-6-arylpyridines, 2-thienyl-4-furyl-6-arylpyridines, and rigid analogues of 2,4,6-trisubstituted pyridines as shown in Figure 1 inhibited human DNA topo I or/and topo IIα.(13, 15) First, we evaluated the effect of synthesized compounds on human DNA topo I and IIα with the relaxation assay using supercoiled pBR322 plasmid DNA. Camptothecin and etoposide, well-known topo I and II inhibitors, respectively, were used as positive controls. The inhibitory activities of compounds on topo I and IIα are depicted in Figure S1, and their quantified activities using densitometric analysis are listed in Table 1. Most of the benzo[4,5]furo[3,2-b]pyridine compounds (1–14) inhibited both topo I and IIα except compound 3, whereas chromeno[4,3-b]pyridine compounds (15–29) inhibited only topo IIα activity, with the exception of compounds 17, 18, and 19. Compounds 1–14, chlorinated compounds in the furan ring, showed the tendency of attenuating topo I inhibitory activity at a treatment of 100 μM (11 (77.1%) vs 1 (40.2%); 10 (59.0%) vs 2 (38.4%)), while no considerable inhibition of topo IIα activity was observed. In compounds 15–29, chlorination on the furan ring showed no noticeable effect on topo I and IIα inhibition (25 vs 15; 26 vs 16). The substitution in R1 position in compounds 1–14 with 2-chlorofuranyl in R2 changed topo I and IIα inhibitory activities of compounds in the order of m-/p-hydroxyphenyl > 2-furanyl > 2-/3-thienyl > phenyl in R1. A similar tendency was observed for topo IIα inhibitory activities of compounds in compounds 15–29 but not for topo I inhibitory activities. In general, hydroxyphenyl in R1 with 2-chlorofuranyl in R2 showed better activity; therefore, we synthesized compounds which have o-/m-/p-hydroxyphenyl in R1 and each of phenyl, 2-furyl, or 3-furyl in R2 of both series of compounds. Interestingly, these modified compounds 15–29 lost topo I inhibitory activity with the exception of compounds 17, 18, and 19 but retained potent topo IIα inhibitory activity. Compound 8 showed strong topo I and IIα dual inhibitory activity, 63.3% and 81.7% at 100 μM, which is stronger than camptothecin (53.4%) and etoposide (62.7%). Compound 22 had stronger inhibitory activity on topo IIα (84.0%) than topo I (6.3%). We further determined the IC50 values of compounds 8 and 22 against recombinant topo I and topo IIα to conclude precisely their inhibitory potency. The values of IC50 of compound 8 are 65.2 ± 5.7 μM and 13.4 ± 1.2 μM against topo I and topo IIα, while that of compound 22 against topo IIα is 60.2 ± 9.5 μM (Table 2).
    Table 1. Inhibitory Activities of Compounds on Topo I and IIα

    Inhibitory Effect of Synthesized Compounds on Cell Proliferation

    We tested the ability of compounds to inhibit cell proliferation in various human cancer cells by measuring mitochondrial dehydrogenase activity. Four different human cell lines were used: HCT15 (human colorectal adenocarcinoma cell line), T47D (human breast cancer cell line), DU145 (human prostate cancer cell line), HEK293 (human embryonic kidney cell line). The inhibitory activities are expressed as micromolar concentration of IC50 and listed in Table 3. Adriamycin, camptothecin, and etoposide were used as positive controls. Most of the compounds displayed potent antiproliferative activity in human cancer cell lines in relatively lower micromolar concentrations compared to that in HEK293 cell line. Seventy-two hours of treatment with compounds 8 and 22 inhibited human breast cancer T47D cells with IC50 values of 0.83 ± 0.04 μM and 0.54 ± 0.01 μM, human colorectal adenocarcinoma HCT15 cells with IC50 values of 0.15 ± 0.01 μM and 0.005 ± 0.00004 μM, and human embryonic HEK293 cells with IC50 values of 4.93 ± 0.07 μM and 5.69 ± 0.21 μM, respectively. We chose compounds 8 and 22 for further studies to evaluate their mode of action in inhibiting topo I and/or topo II and the antiproliferative effect based on their potent inhibitory activity against recombinant topos along with their relatively strong cytotoxicity in various cancer cell lines (Tables 1–3).
    Table 3. Cytotoxicity of Compounds against Several Cancer Cells

    Inhibitory Effect of Compounds 8 and 22 on the Topo IIα Mediated Decatenation of kDNA

    One of the most important roles of topo IIα is to control the decatenation checkpoint. Topo IIα is required to separate knotted sister chromatids before chromosome segregation occurs in mitosis.(23) Therefore, we evaluated the topo IIα inhibitory activities of compounds 8 and 22 with ATP-dependent decatenation assay using kinetoplast DNA (kDNA) as a substrate. Ellipticine, a known DNA intercalating and DNA binding topo II inhibitor,(24) was used as a positive control. The decatenation of kDNA by catalytic activity of topo IIα forms different decatenation outcomes such as nicked, relaxed, and supercoiled DNA. The catenated kDNA appears in agarose gel at the top and cannot enter into the gel because of its big size while other decatenated DNA enters the well as shown in Figure 4A. Ellipticine inhibited 65.3% of topo IIα-mediated decatenation of kDNA at 100 μM which is similar to previously reported results.(25) Compound 8 inhibited 6.4% of topo IIα-mediated decatenation of kDNA at 100 μM and 30.3% at 300 μM, while compound 22 inhibited 52.2% at 100 μM and 69.3% at 300 μM (Figure 4). Compound 8 had stronger inhibitory activity on topo IIα-mediated DNA relaxation (Tables 1 and 2) than compound 22, but compound 22 inhibited topo IIα-mediated DNA decatenation with stronger extent than compound 8 (Figure 4).

    Inhibitory Effect of Compounds 8 and 22 on Endogenous Topos and Selectivity for Endogenous Topo IIα

    To determine whether in vitro inhibitory activities of compounds on DNA relaxation and decatenation occur against endogenous topos, a cell-based DNA relaxation assay was performed with nuclear lysates of MCF7, T47D, and HCT15 cells treated with 5 or 10 μM concentrations of compounds 8 and 22 using 100 ng of pBR322 plasmid as a substrate. T47D and HCT15 cells were utilized because both compounds showed potent antiproliferative activity in these cell lines (Table 3), and another human breast cancer cell, MCF7, was tested. In the absence of compounds, cell lysate made the supercoiled plasmid completely relaxed or linearized because of endogenous topos in the nuclear lysates (the second lanes in Figure 5). Treatment of 10 μM 8 (69.2%) and 22 (86.7%) inhibited more strongly endogenous topos action than 50 μM etoposide (37.8%) in MCF7 (Figure 5A). The inhibitory activities of compound 22 at 10 μM were 76.2% in T47D and 79.5% in HCT15 which were potent as much as in MCF7 and more effective than 50 μM etoposide (59.5% in T47D and 40.4% in HCT15), while treatment of 10 μM compound 8 showed weaker inhibition in T47D (5.6%) and HCT15 (32.1%) than 50 μM etoposide (Figure 5B and Figure 5C). Since compound 22 inhibited selectively the DNA relaxation activity of recombinant topo IIα over topo I (Table 1 and Figure S1) as well as endogenous topos with stronger potency than etoposide, we wanted to evaluate the selectivity of compound 22 for topo IIα. After the topo IIα expression was selectively decreased using topo IIα-targeting lentivirus-mediated small hairpin RNA interference in HCT15 cells (Figure 5E), only treatment of compound 22 showed the distinctive reduction of inhibitory activity (14.8% (Figure 5D) vs 79.5% in the parent HCT15 cells (Figure 5C)), while the inhibitory activity of etoposide (39.0% vs 40.4%) and compound 8 (31.6% vs 32.1%) was not changed much. Etoposide inhibited both topo IIα and topo IIβ through binding to both enzymes,(26) and compound 8 inhibited both topo I and recombinant topo IIα (Tables 1 and 2). Therefore, etoposide or compound 8 could still target the relaxation activity of topo IIβ or topo I unlike compound 22 after topo IIα was knocked down, while compound 22 worked on less amount of the topo IIα after knock-down, reflecting that compound 22 might function as a topo IIα-specific inhibitor.

    Compounds 8 and 22 Acted as Nonintercalating Catalytic Inhibitors

    A cleavable complex assay provides insight into understanding the mode of action of compounds such as topo poison or catalytic inhibitor.(27, 28) Topo poisons act by stabilizing transiently formed covalent enzyme–DNA complex, known as “cleavable complex”, through formation of ternary complex of drug–cleaved DNA–enzyme and thus leading to the rapid formation of DNA strand break.(9, 27a) The rest of the topo inhibitors besides topo poisons can be grouped as a topo catalytic inhibitor. Both representative compounds inhibited the recombinant topo IIα with more potency than etoposide at 100 μM in vitro (Figure S1 and Table 1); therefore, the cleavable complex assay was performed with topo IIα in the current study. In cleavage complex assay, the pBR322 plasmid was initially relaxed by preincubation with topo IIα for 10 min and then the compound was added and incubated for an additional 20 min at 37 °C. Treatment of compounds 8 and 22 did not produce the linear form of DNA in contrast to etoposide, known as a topo II poison(27b) (Figure 6A). This result indicates that compounds 8 and 22 did not stabilize enzyme–DNA cleavable complex; therefore, they did not act as a classical topo II poison even at 300 μM concentration, yet act as topo II catalytic inhibitors. Topo II catalytic inhibitors are classified into two types such as DNA intercalators and nonintercalators.(9, 10, 29, 30) In order to determine the intercalating or nonintercalating ability of potent compounds, the retardation of pBR322 helix DNA in the migration during gel electrophoresis was simply checked in the presence or absence of compounds. Ethidium bromide, a well-known DNA intercalator,(31) induced noticeable retardation in DNA migration as shown in Figure 6B, like the previous observation,(32) while compounds 8 and 22 did not. In addition, a DNA unwinding assay was carried out using a supercoiled pHOT1 DNA as a substrate, since unwinding of the double stranded DNA helix is a practical characteristic of intercalating drugs.(33) As shown in Figure 6C, amsacrine (m-AMSA), the DNA intercalator,(9, 10) blocked unwinding of pHOT1 DNA in the presence of excess topo I in a dose-dependent manner which is consistent with the result previously reported.(26) Neither compound 8 nor compound 22 blocked DNA unwinding at high concentration up to 1000 μM treatment. Some compounds targeting the ATP-binding site of topo IIα ATP binding domain have been reported as nonintercalative topo IIα catalytic inhibitors such as bisdioxopiperazines of 1,2-bis(3,5-dioxopiperazin-1-yl)ethane (ICRF-154),(9b) sobuzoxane (MST-16),(9c) dexrazoxane (ICRF-187),(9d, 34) and xanthone analogue.(12) The ATPase assay was performed for compounds, and results are depicted in Figure 6D. Novobiocin, a topo II-catalyzed ATP hydrolysis inhibitor,(35) inhibited topo IIα-mediated ATP hydrolysis by 45.9 ± 3.8% at 200 μM and 60.2 ± 2.5% at 400 μM. Compound 8 very slightly inhibited ATP hydrolysis (13.9 ± 3.6% at 400 μM treatment), whereas compound 22 did not inhibit it at the same concentrations as novobiocin and compound 8. On the basis of the results of cleavable complex, DNA intercalation, unwinding and ATPase assay, it can be concluded that compound 8 functions as a nonintercalating topo I and II dual inhibitor with slight blocking of ATP binding and compound 22 acts as a nonintercalating topo IIα inhibitor without interrupting ATP hydrolysis activity.

    Compounds 8 and 22 Induced Less DNA Damage than Etoposide in MCF7 and T47D Cells

    Most topo-targeting anticancer drugs are severely toxic, increasing DNA strand breaks through the formation of a cleavable complex.(1, 9, 10) The comet assay was carried out to measure toxicity induced by the accumulation of DNA strand breaks.(36) Observations using an inverted fluorescence microscope revealed that etoposide induced severe DNA damage at 10 μM in MCF7 cells and 5 μM in T47D cells which is consistent with previous observations due to its mode of action as a topo poison.(37, 38) Compound 22 induced comet at 10 μM treatment for 24 h with MCF7 with much less extent than etoposide but almost no DNA damage in T47D. Compound 8 caused almost no DNA damage in both tested cells (Figure 7). These findings suggest that compounds 8 and 22 may represent a novel structural class of nonintercalative topo I and II catalytic inhibitor and topo IIα-specific catalytic inhibitor that are not highly genotoxic.

    Compounds 8 and 22 Were More Efficient at Inhibiting the Clonogenic Survival and Viability of MCF7 Breast Cancer Cells Than MCF10A Normal Breast Cells

    The clonogenic cell survival assay is a long-term cell viability assay which determines the ability of cell to proliferate indefinitely, thus keeping its reproductive ability to form a colony.(32, 39) This assay was done to investigate the anticolony forming ability of compounds 8 and 22 in MCF7 human breast cancer cells and MCF10A human normal breast cells. MCF7 cell line was selected because compounds 8 and 22 inhibited most potently the endogenous topos in MCF7 (Figure 5). MCF7 and MCF10A cells were treated for 24 h with increasing concentrations of compounds 8 and 22 (up to 4 μM), and the assay was performed according to the protocol described in the method section. Compounds 8 and 22 caused a dose-dependent decrease in colony-forming ability (Figure 8A). The % survival of MCF10A cells decreased to 20% after 3 μM treatment of each compound 8 and 22, while that of MCF7 cells was almost 0% in a same concentration of the treatment. Compound 8 showed significant anticolony forming ability in MCF7 that was similar to that of etoposide but was less effective in MCF10A, whereas etoposide showed stronger anticolony forming ability in MCF10A than in MCF7 (Figure 8A). According to these data, it appears to be that compounds 8 and 22 were more effective at inhibiting the proliferation of breast cancer cells than normal epithelial breast cells unlike etoposide. To confirm the antiproliferative activities of compounds 8 and 22 in breast cancer cells, we carried out a cell viability assay using MCF7 and MCF10A cells. Compounds 8 and 22 decreased the viability of MCF7 breast cancer cells more efficiently in a dose-dependent manner compared to etoposide (Figure 8B). From these experiments, potent antiproliferative activities of compounds 8 and 22 were confirmed.

    Compounds 8 and 22 Inhibited Wound Healing in HEK293 and T47D Cells

    The wound healing assay is a classic and commonly used method for studying the effect of antitumor agents on cell migration and its underlying biology.(40, 41) The effects of compounds on the migration and interaction capability of HEK293 and T47D cells were assessed using a scratch–wound healing assay according to the method previously reported.(42) HEK293 has been often used for testing the cell migration.(32, 41b) MCF7 and HCT15 cancer cells did not migrate fast enough to observe the difference between treated and untreated conditions. Therefore, HEK293 and T47D cells were chosen. A wound was made by scratching the monolayer of cells with a sterile microtip which was then inspected after the treatment of 10 μM 8 or 22. The untreated control cells migrated across the well in a time-dependent manner. However, cell migration in treated cells was inhibited in a time-dependent manner. After 72 h, the control HECK293 cells migrated and completely covered the wound while the gap of the treated cells increased with time (Figure 9A). The rate of covering the wound in untreated control T47D cells was slower than that of HEK293, but the wound gaps in 8- and 22-treated T47D cells were bigger than control with increased treating time (Figure 9B). The results from this assay in conjunction with the clonogenic and MTT cell viability assays reveal that compounds 8 and 22 were able to inhibit colony formation, viability, and migration of cancer cells (Figures 8 and 9).

    Compounds 8 and 22 Induced G1-Phase Arrest and Apoptosis in T47D Cells

    We investigated the effects of compounds on the cell cycle progression of T47D breast cancer cells using fluorescence activated cell sorter (FACS) by staining with propidium iodide. Figure 10 demonstrates the cell cycle profile of T47D cells after exposure to various concentrations of compounds 8 (0, 0.05, 0.1, and 0.5 μM) and 22 (0, 0.005, 0.01, 0.02, and 0.025 μM) for 24 h and exposure for various incubation times (0, 4, 8, 12, and 24 h) at the concentrations of 0.5 μM for compound 8 and 0.02 μM for compound 22. The G1 phase fraction was substantially increased by compounds 8 and 22 in a time- and dose-dependent manner. Thus, compounds 8 and 22 induced T47D cell apoptosis in addition to G1 arrest through a different mechanism of action from etoposide which is known to induce G2/M-phase arrest in various cancer cell lines.(43) We further examined the expression levels of apoptosis-related proteins such as cleaved caspase-3 and cleaved poly ADP-ribose polymerase (PARP) in T47D cells through Western blot analysis to confirm the apoptotic effect of compounds 8 and 22. As shown in Figure 11A and Figure 11B, treatment of both compounds 8 and 22 induced caspase-3 activation and consequently PARP activation. The maximum PARP activation was reached by compound 8 with 5 μM treatment for 24 h and by compound 22 with 10 μM treatment for 24 h. Induction of apoptosis by both compounds 8 and 22 showed a similar pattern to those of etoposide (topo II poison) and merbarone (topo II catalytic inhibitor) that cause PARP cleavage followed by caspase-3 cleavage.(44, 45) In order to confirm 8- and 22-induced apoptosis, FITC-conjugated annexin V and PI double staining flow cytometry analysis was performed after treatment of compounds 8 and 22 for 24 h with T47D cells in designated concentrations in Figure 11C and Figure 11D. The populations of late apoptotic cells (annexin V+/PI+) were increased in a dose-dependent manner after treatment of both compounds. More increase in the annexin V+/PI+ cells with treatment of compound 22 (68.7 ± 3.7% at 20 μM) was observed than compound 8 (21.0 ± 1.5% at 20 μM).

    Compounds 8 and 22 Inhibited Tumor Growth in an in Vivo Xenograft Mouse Model

    In vivo antitumor effect of compounds 8 and 22 was examined with HCT15 subcutaneously implanted xenografted tumors, since both compounds showed the most potent cytotoxicity against HCT15 cells (Table 3) with potent inhibitory activity against endogenous topos in HCT15 cells (Figure 5). When HCT15 subcutaneously implanted xenografted tumors reached 150–250 mm3 (21 days after cell injection), mice were randomly grouped (four mice per group) and treated in intratumoral injection with either vehicle alone (control) or compound once (20 mg/kg). As shown in Figure 12, the tumor volumes and weight of excised tumors treated with compound 8 were significantly reduced versus untreated controls. Treatment of compound 22 also showed clear reduction in tumor volumes and weights but with no statistical significance. Sections of compound 8- or 22-treated and control tumors were stained with hematoxylin–eosine (H&E) and Ki-67, a cell proliferative marker. The expression levels of Ki-67 in 8- and 22-treated groups were significantly lower than that of the control group (Figure 12C). These results support that compounds 8 and 22 have in vivo antitumor activity.

    Methylated Compounds 8 and 22 Improved Metabolic Stability and PK Parameters with Remaining Inhibitory Activity against Endogenous Topos

    Both compounds 8 and 22 were metabolized quickly in the tested human, dog, rat, and mouse liver microsomes. The half-lives (t1/2) of compounds 8 and 22 are less than 39 min in all tested microsomes (Tables S2 and S3 in Supporting Information). An in vivo pharmacokinetic (PK) study was conducted in male rats after oral administration of compounds 8 and 22 at 5 mg/kg. In all plasma samples collected up to 24 h postdose, the concentration of compounds was measurable, indicating that the current method is adequate for PK studies in rats. The PK parameters of compounds 8 and 22 were calculated and listed in Table S4. The Cmax, Tmax, and AUC0–24h of compound 8 were 0.02 ± 0.01 μg/mL, 1.00 ± 0.00 h, and 0.15 ± 0.00 μg·h/mL, respectively; those of compound 22 were 0.02 ± 0.01 μg/mL, 4.00 ± 0.00 h, and 0.10 ± 0.01 μg·h/mL, respectively. Compounds 8 and 22 were rapidly metabolized in vivo, and their bioavailability was less than 3% (Table S4). Therefore, we tried the modification of compounds with methylation on hydroxyl group as shown in Figure 13A,B and Scheme 2, named 8-M and 22-M, to overcome the rapid degradation of compounds 8 and 22 during liver and blood metabolism, thereby improving their PK parameters. The topo I and/or IIα inhibitory activities of compounds 8-M and 22-M were lost in the in vitro assay after methylation on hydroxyl groups of compounds 8 and 22 (Figure 13 C), but surprisingly their inhibitory activity against endogenous topos was stronger than that of the original compounds at 5 μM concentration (Figures 5A vs Figure 13D) (compound 8, 2.5% vs compound 8-M, 40.2% and compound 22, 0.5% vs compound 22-M, 33.8%) and was similar to that of the original compounds at 10 μM treatment. The metabolic stability and PK parameters of compounds 8-M and 22-M were significantly improved as compared to the original compounds (Figure S1 and Tables 4 and 5). The t1/2 of compounds 8-M (1.79 h) and 22-M (1.81 h) were 3.4 and 3.5 times longer than compounds 8 (31.4 min) and 22 (31.1 min), respectively, in human liver microsomes. The PK parameters of compound 8-M and 22-M are listed in Table 5. The bioavailability of compounds 8-M and 22-M are 41.3% and 33.2%, respectively. The reasons can be inferred as to why methylated compounds were more effective at inhibiting endogenous topo compared to hydroxy compounds at 5 μM concentration. First, replacing the hydroxy group with the methoxy group enhanced metabolic stability in diverse type of liver microsomes and improvement of PK parameters in rat plasma. Second, the methoxy group may be reverted to a hydroxyl group in cells by demethylation phase I metabolism, therefore functioning as catalytic topo I and/or IIα inhibitors much like compounds 8 and 22. Third, introduction of a methoxy group may augment the cell permeability of compounds.

    Conclusion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    We designed and synthesized novel topo I and IIα inhibitors comprising a benzo[4,5]furo[3,2-b]pyridine core (compounds 1–14) and topo IIα inhibitors consisting of chromeno[4,3-b]pyridine core (compounds 15–29). The modes of action of the most potent compounds 8 and 22 from each core structure were evaluated with various assays such as cell cytotoxicity, wound healing, in vitro and in vivo topo I and IIα relaxation, decatenation, DNA cleavable complex, DNA intercalation, DNA unwinding, and topo IIα-mediated ATPase assays. Compound 8 was determined to be a nonintercalative topo I and II dual catalytic inhibitor, and compound 22 was determined to be a nonintercalative topo IIα specific catalytic inhibitor. These two catalytic inhibitors exhibited potent anticancer activity in MCF7, T47D, and HCT15 cells and in vivo xenografted mouse model. Both compounds induced apoptosis in addition to G1 arrest in T47D human breast cancer cells with much less DNA toxicity than etoposide, a well-known topo II poison drug. Being a good chemotherapeutic target of topos for long periods of time can be attributed to their capability of resolving DNA topological problems inevitably encountered during cell proliferation of various types of cancers.(1-4, 9) However, it has been reported that topo poisons among drugs targeting topos provoke severe DNA toxicity due to their mode of action to stabilize the enzyme–DNA transient complex, leading to generation of truncated DNAs.(1, 9, 10) The development of catalytic inhibitors of topo IIα is essentially needed if considering a growing repertoire of topos as an anticancer target as well as necessity of less DNA toxic topo catalytic inhibitors;(10) Human epithelial growth factor receptor 2 (HER2) overexpressing cancer patients have generally developed severe resistance against treatment with HER2 extracellular domain-targeting antibody drugs. Topo IIα inhibitors have been co-treated to overcome these drug-mediated resistances.(46, 47) Compound 22-M might be reverted to compound 22 in cells through demethylation phase I metabolism and inhibited endogenous topo IIα with much stronger intensity than etoposide and with good bioavailability when orally administered. Conclusively, the results of the current study provide noticeable rationale to design orally available anticancer drugs targeting topo I and/or topo IIα with less side effects caused by formation of DNA truncation.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    General Chemistry

    Compounds used as starting materials and reagents were obtained from Aldrich Chemical Co., Junsei, or other chemical companies and utilized without further purification. HPLC grade acetonitrile (ACN) and methanol were purchased from Burdick and Jackson, USA. Thin-layer chromatography (TLC) and column chromatography were performed with Kieselgel 60 F254 (Merck) and silica gel (Kieselgel 60, 230–400 mesh, Merck), respectively. Since all the compounds prepared contain an aromatic ring, they were visualized and detected on TLC plates with UV light (short wave, long wave or both). NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AMX 250 (250 MHz, FT) for 1H NMR and 62.5 MHz for 13C NMR, and chemical shifts were calibrated according to TMS. Chemical shifts (δ) were recorded in ppm and coupling constants (J) in hertz (Hz). Melting points were determined in open capillary tubes on an Electrothermal 1A 9100 digital melting point apparatus and were uncorrected. The purity of all the final compounds was checked by HPLC and HRMS analyses and is described as percent (%), and retention time is given in minutes. HPLC analyses were performed using two Shimadzu LC-10AT pumps gradient-controlled HPLC system equipped with Shimadzu system controller (SCL-10A VP) and photodiode array detector (SPD-M10A VP) utilizing Shimadzu Class VP program. Sample volume of 10 μL was injected in Waters X-Terra 5 μm reverse-phase C18 column (4.6 mm × 250 mm) with a gradient elution of 85–100% of B in A for 10 min followed by 100–85% of B in A for 20 min at a flow rate of 1.0 mL/min at 254 nm UV detection, where mobile phase A was doubly distilled water with 50 mM ammonium formate (AF) and B was 90% ACN in water with 20 mM AF. The purity of all the synthesized compounds is in the range of 95.9–100%. ESI LC/MS analyses were performed with a Finnigan LCQ Advantage LC/MS/MS spectrometer utilizing Xcalibur program. For ESI LC/MS, LC was performed with a 1 μL injection volume on a Waters Atlantis T3, 3 μm reverse-phase C18 column (2.1 mm × 50 mm) with a gradient elution from 20% to 100% of B in A for 6.5 min followed by 100% to 20% of B in A for 6 min and 20% of B in A for 2.5 min at a flow rate of 200 μL/min, where mobile phase A was 100% distilled water with 20 mM AF and mobile phase B was 100% ACN. MS ionization conditions were the following: sheath gas flow rate, 40 arb; aux gas flow rate, 0 arb; I spray voltage, 5.3 kV; capillary temperature, 275 °C; capillary voltage, 27 V; tube lens offset, 45 V. Mass spectra (FAB) were obtained using a Jeol JMS700 high-resolution mass spectrometer (analyzer type: magenetic sector–electric sector double focusing mass analyzer) at the Korea Basic Science Center, Daegu, Korea.

    General Method for Preparation of II (R1 = a–g)

    Aryl methyl ketone I (R1 = a–g) was treated with pyridine and equivalent amount of iodine. The mixture was then refluxed for 3 h. Precipitate formed during reaction was cooled to room temperature which was filtered and washed with cold pyridine followed by drying overnight to yield 45.3–98.3% of II (R1 = a–g). Compounds were used without further purification.

    General Method for the Preparation of IV (R2 = f–i)

    3-Coumaranone and arylaldehyde III (R2 = f–i) were dissolved in an equivalent amount in dichloromethane. After complete dissolution, aluminum oxide was added slowly to the reaction mixture at room temperature. The reaction mixture was stirred for 1–3 h until precipitation was observed. Then the mixture was cooled for 30 min, filtered, and washed with ethyl acetate. The precipitate was dried to give compounds IV (R2 = f–i) in 67.9–94.2% yield.

    General Method for the Preparation of V (R2 = f–i)

    4-Chromanone was dissolved in ethanol followed by the addition of an equivalent amount of arylaldehyde III (R2 = f–i). After complete dissolution, 5% aqueous solution of NaOH was added slowly to the reaction mixture at room temperature. On addition of NaOH, precipitation was observed, cooled for 30 min, filtered, and washed with water and cold methanol. The precipitate was dried to give compounds V (R2 = f–i) in 63.0–94.8% yield.

    General Method for the Preparation of 1–29

    Previously synthesized intermediates of 3-coumaranone IV (R2 = f–i) or 4-chromanone V (R2 = f–i) were reacted with pyridinium iodide salts, II (R1 = a–g), in the presence of anhydrous ammonium acetate and glacial acetic acid. The mixture was then refluxed for 12–24 h under nitrogen gas. The solvent was evaporated, and the residue was extracted with ethyl acetate (90 mL) and washed with water (30 mL × 3) and saturated NaCl solution (30 mL). The organic layer was dried with magnesium sulfate and filtered. The filtrate was concentrated under reduced pressure and dried in a vacuum pump, which was then purified by silica gel column chromatography with a gradient elution of ethyl acetate and n-hexane to afford solid compounds 1–29 in the yield of 20.9–58.6%.

    4-(4-(5-Chlorofuran-2-yl)benzofuro[3,2-b]pyridin-2-yl)phenol (1)

    The compound was synthesized as described in above procedure with IV (R2 = i) (0.49 g, 2 mmol), II (R1 = e) (1.36 g, 4 mmol), NH4OAc (1.43 g, 18.6 mmol), and glacial acetic acid (4 mL) to yield 243 mg (0.67 mmol, 33.7%) as a yellow solid,** Rf = 0.24 (ethyl acetate/n-hexane = 1:3, v/v). Mp: 288.2–289.3 °C. HPLC: purity 100%. Retention time: 13.01 min. ESI LC/MS m/z calcd for C21H12ClNO3 [MH]+ 362.06; found 362.28. 1H NMR (250 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 9.78 (br, 1H, 2-phenyl 4-OH), 8.22 (d, J = 7.5 Hz, 1H, benzofuro H-7), 8.10–8.06 (m, 3H, 2-phenyl H-2, H-6, pyridine H-3), 7.86 (d, J = 8.2 Hz, 1H, benzofuro H-4), 7.69 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 1H, benzofuro H-5), 7.62 (d, J = 3.5 Hz, 1H, 4-furan H-3), 7.52 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 1H, benzofuro H-6), 6.94–6.87 (m, 3H, 2-phenyl H-3, H-5, 4-furan H-4). 13C NMR (62.5 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 159.36, 158.01, 154.31, 147.56, 144.77, 143.06, 138.41, 130.63, 130.23, 129.19 (2C), 125.04, 123.57, 121.78, 121.58, 116.85, 116.42 (2C), 113.50, 111.64, 111.00. HRMS (FAB): calcd for C21H12ClNO3 [M]+ 361.0506; found 361.0504.

    3-(4-(5-Chlorofuran-2-yl)benzofuro[3,2-b]pyridin-2-yl)phenol (2)

    The compound was synthesized as described in above procedure with IV (R2 = i) (0.49 g, 2 mmol), II (R1 = d) (0.85g, 2.5 mmol), NH4OAc (1.54 g, 20 mmol), and glacial acetic acid (4 mL) to yield 327 mg (0.90 mmol, 45.3%) as a yellow solid. Rf = 0.35 (ethyl acetate/n-hexane = 1:3, v/v). Mp: 242.4–243.9 °C. HPLC: purity 98.3%. Retention time: 12.78 min. ESI LC/MS m/z calcd for C21H12ClNO3 [MH]+ 362.06; found 362.38. 1H NMR (250 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.31 (d, J = 7.9 Hz, 1H, benzofuro H-7), 8.06 (s, 1H, pyridine H-3), 7.73 (s, 1H, 2-phenyl H-2), 7.62–7.34 (m, 6H, 2-phenyl H-5, H-6, 4-furan H-3, benzofuro H-4, H-5, H-6), 6.91 (d, J = 7.5 Hz, 1H, 2-phenyl H-4), 6.45 (d, J = 3.4 Hz, 1H, 4-furan H-4). 13C NMR (62.5 MHz, CDCl3) δ 158.67 (2C), 158.10, 154.11, 147.39, 144.92, 143.48, 140.64, 138.53, 130.71, 125.15, 123.45, 121.79, 121.51, 118.59, 117.05, 116.92, 114.51, 113.56, 112.66, 111.05. HRMS (FAB): calcd for C21H12ClNO3 [M]+ 361.0506; found 361.0504.

    4-(5-Chlorofuran-2-yl)-2-phenylbenzofuro[3,2-b]pyridine (3)

    The compound was synthesized as described in above procedure with IV (R2 = i) (0.49 g, 2 mmol), II (R1 = g) (0.70 g, 2.2 mmol), NH4OAc (1.43 g, 18.6 mmol), and glacial acetic acid (4 mL) to yield 394 mg (1.14 mmol, 57.1%) as a yellow solid. Rf = 0.56 (ethyl acetate/n-hexane = 1:3, v/v). Mp: 225.1–226.2 °C. HPLC: purity 98.6%. Retention time: 15.25 min. ESI LC/MS m/z calcd for C21H12ClNO2 [MH]+ 346.06; found 346.28. 1H NMR (250 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.30 (dd, J = 7.6, 0.5 Hz, 1H, benzofuro H-7), 8.15 (br, 2H, 2-phenyl H-2, H-6), 8.07 (s, 1H, pyridine H-3), 7.65–7.39 (m, 7H, 2-phenyl H-3, H-4, H-5, 4-furan H-3, benzofuro H-4, H-5, H-6), 6.44 (d, J = 3.5 Hz, 1H, 4-furan H-4). 13C NMR (62.5 MHz, CDCl3) δ 157.73, 154.29, 146.89, 144.67, 143.39, 139.54, 138.57, 129.19, 128.78 (2C), 128.73, 127.29 (2C), 123.78, 123.51, 121.57, 121.24, 115.95, 112.34, 112.17, 109.34. HRMS (FAB): calcd for C21H12ClNO2 [M]+ 345.0557; found 345.0554.

    4-(5-Chlorofuran-2-yl)-2-(furan-2-yl)benzofuro[3,2-b]pyridine (4)

    The compound was synthesized as described in above procedure with IV (R2 = i) (0.49 g, 2 mmol), II (R1 = f) (0.68 g, 2.2 mmol), NH4OAc (1.43 g, 18.6 mmol), and glacial acetic acid (4 mL) to yield 308 mg (0.92 mmol, 46.0%) as a yellow solid. Rf = 0.12 (ethyl acetate/n-hexane = 1:3, v/v). Mp: 190.6–193.2 °C. HPLC: purity 95.1%. Retention time: 14.30 min. ESI LC/MS m/z calcd for C19H10ClNO3 [MH]+ 336.04; found 336.21. 1H NMR (250 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.28 (d, J = 7.7 Hz, benzofuro H-7), 8.06 (s, 1H, pyridine H-3), 7.63–7.52 (m, 3H, 2-furan H-5, benzofuro H-4, H-6), 7.46–7.39 (m, 2H, 4-furan H-3, benzofuro H-5), 7.16 (d, J = 3.1 Hz, 1H, 2-furan H-3), 6.56 (dd, J = 3.4, 1.8 Hz, 1H, 2-furan H-4), 6.43 (d, J = 3.5 Hz, 1H, 4-furan H-4). 13C NMR (62.5 MHz, CDCl3) δ 157.69, 153.67, 146.68, 146.12, 144.55, 143.23, 143.08, 138.72, 129.30, 123.77, 123.16, 121.71, 121.32, 116.12, 112.15, 112.09, 110.57, 109.35, 108.43. HRMS (FAB): calcd for C19H10ClNO3 [M]+ 335.0349; found 335.0349.

    4-(5-Chlorofuran-2-yl)-2-(thiophen-2-yl)benzofuro[3,2-b]pyridine (5)

    The compound was synthesized as described in above procedure with IV (R2 = i) (0.49 g, 2 mmol), II (R1 = a) (0.72 g, 2.2 mmol), NH4OAc (1.43 g, 18.6 mmol), and glacial acetic acid (4 mL) to yield 359 mg (1.02 mmol, 51.2%) as a yellow solid. Rf = 0.50 (ethyl acetate/n-hexane = 1:3, v/v). Mp: 182.8–185.3 °C. HPLC: purity 96.5%. Retention time: 16.78 min. ESI LC/MS m/z calcd for C19H10ClNO2S [MH]+ 352.02; found 352.22. 1H NMR (250 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.26 (d, J = 7.5 Hz, 1H, benzofuro H-7), 7.99 (s, 1H, pyridine H-3), 7.71 (dd, J = 3.6, 1.0 Hz, 1H, 2-thiophene H-3), 7.61 (d, J = 8.2 Hz, 1H, benzofuro H-4), 7.56 (dt, J = 8.2, 1.3 Hz, 1H, benzofuro H-6), 7.46–7.39 (m, 3H, 2-thiophene H-5, 4-furan H-3, benzofuro H-5), 7.14 (dt, J = 4.4, 1.3 Hz, 1H, 2-thiophene H-4), 6.44 (d, J = 3.5 Hz, 1H, 4-furan H-4). 13C NMR (62.5 MHz, CDCl3) δ 157.66, 149.37, 146.62, 144.82, 144.41, 143.18, 138.64, 129.24, 128.02, 127.24, 124.74, 123.74, 123.19, 121.72, 121.26, 116.13, 112.12, 110.65, 109.38. HRMS (FAB): calcd for C19H10ClNO2S [M]+ 351.0121; found 351.0118.

    4-(5-Chlorofuran-2-yl)-2-(thiophen-3-yl)benzofuro[3,2-b]pyridine (6)

HRMS (FAB): calcd for C22H15NO3 [M]+ 341.1052; found 341.1050.

    General Method for the Preparation of 8-M and 22-M

    A mixture of compound 8 or 22, methyl iodide, and potassium carbonate in tetrahydrofuran was stirred at 20 °C for 12–24 h. The mixture was extracted with ethyl acetate and washed with water and brine. The organic layer was dried with magnesium sulfate and filtered. The filtrate was evaporated at reduced pressure and dried to yield a solid (94.6–97.1%).

    2-(3-Methoxyphenyl)-4-phenylbenzofuro[3,2-b]pyridine (8-M)

    The compound was synthesized as described in above procedure with 8 (57 mg, 0.17 mmol), K2CO3 (0.5 g), CH3I (0.5 mL), and tetrahydrofuran (2 mL) to yield 58 mg (0.16 mmol, 97.1%) as a light yellow solid. Rf = 0.59 (ethyl acetate/n-hexane = 1:2, v/v). Mp: 130.3–131.8 °C. HPLC: purity 97.4%. Retention time: 15.86 min. HRMS (FAB): calcd for C24H17NO2 [M]+ 351.1259; found 351.1258.

    2-(3-Methoxyphenyl)-4-phenyl-5H-chromeno[4,3-b]pyridine (22-M)

    The compound was synthesized as described in above procedure with 22 (38 mg, 0.11 mmol), K2CO3 (0.4 g), CH3I (0.4 mL), and tetrahydrofuran (4 mL) to yield 38 mg (0.10 mmol, 94.6%) as a yellow solid. HRMS (FAB): calcd for C25H19NO2 [M]+ 365.1416; found 365.1413.

    Cell Culture

    HEK293, a human kidney embryonic cell line (ATCC CRL-1573), HCT15, a human colon cancer cell line (ATCC CRL-225), T47D, a human breast cancer cell line (ATCC HTB-133), MCF7, a human breast cancer cell line (ATCC HTB-22), MCF10A, a human breast epithelial cell line (ATCC CRL-10317), and DU145, a human prostate cancer cell line (ATCC HTB-81) were purchased from the Korean Cell Line Bank (Seoul, Korea). MCF10A was grown in Dulbecco’s modified Eagle medium with nutrient mixture F-12 (DMEM/F-12, Welgene, Korea), supplemented with 5% (v/v) horse serum, 100 U/mL penicillin, 100 mg/mL streptomycin, 0.5 mg/mL hydrocortisone, 100 ng/mL cholera toxin, 10 mg/mL insulin, 10 ng/mL epidermal growth factor, and 1% (w/v) of l-glutamine (Sigma Chemical Co., USA). HCT15, T47D, MCF7, and DU145 were grown in RPMI 1640 medium (Welgene, Korea), and HEK293 was grown in Dulbecco’s modified Eagle medium (DMEM, Welgene, Korea) in a humidified 5% CO2 incubator kept at 37 °C. Each medium was supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS, Hyclone Laboratories, Inc., USA) and 1% penicillin/streptomycin (Sigma, USA). All media were changed every 2–3 days.

    DNA Topo I Mediated Relaxation Assay in Vitro

    DNA topo I inhibition assay was determined following the method reported by Fukuda et al.(48) with minor modifications. The tested compounds were dissolved in DMSO at a concentration of 20 mM as stock solutions. The activity of DNA topo I was determined by assessing the relaxation of supercoiled DNA pBR322. The mixture of 100 ng of pBR322 DNA (Fermentas, USA) and 1 unit of recombinant human DNA topo I (TopoGEN INC., USA) was incubated with and without the prepared compounds at 37 °C for 30 min in the relaxation buffer (10 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.9), 150 mM NaCl, 0.1% bovine serum albumin, 1 mM spermidine, 5% glycerol). The reaction in the final volume of 10 μL was terminated by adding 2.5 μL of the stop solution containing 5% sarcosyl, 0.0025% bromophenol blue, and 25% glycerol. DNA samples were then electrophoresed on a 0.8% agarose gel at 60 V for 1 h with a running buffer of TAE (Tris-acetate-EDTA). Gels were stained for 30 min in an aqueous solution of ethidium bromide (0.5 μg/mL). DNA bands were visualized by transillumination with UV light and quantitated using AlphaImager (Alpha Innotech Corporation).

    DNA Topo IIα Mediated Relaxation Assay in Vitro

    DNA topo IIα inhibitory activities of compounds were measured as follows. The mixture of 100 ng of supercoiled pBR322 plasmid DNA (Fermentas, USA) and 1 unit of human DNA topo IIα (Usb Corp., USA) were incubated with and without the prepared compounds in the assay buffer (10 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.9) containing 50 mM NaCl, 5 mM MgCl2, 1 mM EDTA, 1 mM ATP, and 15 μg/mL bovine serum albumin) for 30 min at 37 °C. The reaction in a final volume of 10 μL was terminated by the addition of 3 μL of 7 mM EDTA. Reaction products were analyzed as in the DNA topo I mediated relaxation assay in vitro.

    Cell Viability Assay

    To measure the antiproliferative activity of the candidate compounds in various cancer cell lines, cell viability was assessed by measuring mitochondrial dehydrogenase activity with a cell counting kit (CCK-8) purchased from Dojindo Laboratories (Japan). HEK293, HCT15, T47D, DU145, MCF7, and MCF10A cells were seeded in 96-well plates in a density of 104 cells per well, incubated at 37 °C for 24 h, and treated with compounds for 72 h. CCK-8 (10 μL) was added to each well. After another 4 h of incubation at 37 °C, absorbance was measured at 450 nm using an ELISA microplate reader (VersaMax, Molecular Devices). To determine the IC50 values, the absorbance reading at 450 nm was fitted to the four-parameter logistic equation. The compounds of adriamycin, etoposide, and camptothecin were purchased from Sigma (USA) and used as positive controls.

    kDNA Decatenation Assay

    The assay was performed in a total reaction volume of 10 μL containing 50 mM Tris-HCl (pH 8.0), 120 mM KCl, 10 mM MgCl2, 0.5 mM dithiothreitol, 0.5 mM ATP, 30 μg/mL bovine serum albumin, and 75 ng of kDNA. Compounds were then added to a final concentration of 100 or 300 μM. The final amount of DMSO added was 1%. Reactions were initiated by the addition of 3 units of topo IIα, and mixtures were incubated for 30 min at 37 °C. The reaction was terminated by the addition of 2.5 μL of stock solution (5% SDS, 25% Ficoll, and 0.05% bromphenol blue) followed by treatment with 0.25 mg/mL proteinase K (Sigma, USA) at 37 °C for 30 min to eliminate the protein. Samples were resolved by electrophoresis on a 1.2% (w/v) agarose gel containing 0.5 μg/mL ethidium bromide in TAE buffer (100 mM Tris-acetate and 2 mM Na2EDTA, pH 8.3). DNA bands were visualized by UV and photographed and documented with AlphaImager (Alpha Innotech Corporation). For quantitation of the substrate (kDNA) and products of the topo IIα reaction (Nck, SC, and catenanes), the numerical values of intensity profiles of the different lanes were obtained after background subtraction and exported to Microsoft Excel. For each lane, the overall intensity was used to obtain the fraction of intensity for the different bands (kDNA, Nck, and SC). Here, we measured topo IIα activity based on the final products (nicked plus supercoiled minicircles). Positive control (1% DMSO, topo IIα) and negative control (1% DMSO) were used to set up the limit values (1 and 0, respectively).

    Endogenous Topo Inhibition Assay

    To assess the ability of compounds to inhibit the function of topo activity in cells, MCF7, T47D, HCT15, and topo IIα-knockdown HCT cells were treated at designated concentrations in Figures 8 and 13D for 24 h and harvested. The topo IIα-knockdown HCT15 cells was prepared using topo IIα-targeting lentivirus-mediated small hairpin RNA interference (SHCLING-NM_001067, Sigma, USA) with puromycin selection for at least 2 weeks. The extent of protein levels of topo IIα was monitored with Western blot analysis. When the topo IIα protein was downed, then cells were treated with compounds 8 and 22. After a 24 h treatment of compound with cells, nuclear lysate of each cell line was prepared according to the protocol provided by the manufacturer using the nuclear/cytosol fraction kit (BioVision, USA). The protein concentration in each nuclear extract was measured by Bradford assay. The topo reaction was performed with 100 μg of protein of nuclear lysate, 100 ng of pBR322 plasmid as a substrate, and 1× reaction buffer (200 mM Tris-Cl, pH 7.5, 100 mM MgCl2, 10 mM ATP, 10 mM EDTA, 10 mM dithiothreitol, 1.5 mM KCl, and 300 μg/mL bovine serum albumin). The final reaction volume in each tube was kept equal, and the tubes were incubated at 37 °C for 30 min. Similar treatment was also done with a control plasmid of pBR322 containing no lysate to check the effect of the reaction buffer. After incubation, a fixed amount of all the samples was loaded in 0.9% horizontal agarose gel electrophoresis containing ethidium bromide. Gel was run for 4–5 h at 15–20 V. Photographs were taken using an AlphaImager (Alpha Innotech Corporation).

    Clonogenic Assay

    To determine the survival and proliferation of cells after treatment of compounds, the clonogenic assay was performed according to the method previously reported with minor modification.(39, 32) Briefly, 500 cells of MCF7 and MCF10A per well were seeded in six-well plates and grown for 24 h and then treated with different concentrations of compound (1–4 μM) for next 24 h. Thereafter, medium was replaced with fresh medium and incubated for five to six doublings. The colonies developed were fixed with methanol and stained using 0.4% trypan blue. The colonies were counted with bare eyes. The experiments were conducted in triplicate, and the data are represented as percent survival of treated cells vs untreated control.

    Cell Migration Assay

    HEK293 and T47D cells were cultured in a six-well plate to 90% confluence. A clean wound in the cell monolayer across the center of the well was created with a sterile microtip. After 4 h of starvation with low serum media (1% FBS in DMEM), the cells were exposed to each of compounds 8 and 22 (10 μM) for 24 h and were allowed to migrate in the medium. The wound was assessed by a fluorescence inverted microscope at 5× magnification at different time points (0, 12, 24, and 72 h).

    DNA-Topo IIα Cleavable Complex Assay

    A cleavage complex assay was carried out by the method previously reported with minor modification.(32, 28) In brief, 125 ng of supercoiled DNA pBR322 (Fermentas, USA), used as a substrate, was preincubated with 3 units of human DNA topo IIα (Usb Corp., USA) for 10 min, and then each compound was added and incubated at 37 °C for an additional 20 min in a total of 10 μL reaction volume. The reaction was stopped with 1 μL of 10% SDS, followed by digestion with proteinase K and further incubated for 30 min at 45 °C. After the addition of the loading buffer, the reaction was heated for 2 min at 70 °C. Electrophoresis was carried out in a 0.8% agarose gel containing 0.5 μg/mL ethidium bromide in TAE buffer, and further the gel was destained with distilled water for 20 min. DNA bands were visualized by transillumination with UV light, and supercoiled DNA was quantitated using AlphaImager (Alpha Innotech Corporation).

    DNA Unwinding Assay

    An amount of 100 ng of pHOT1 plasmid DNA (TopoGEN INC., USA) was relaxed by incubation with 3 units of human DNA topo I (TopoGEN INC., USA) in topo I reaction buffer (10 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.9) for 30 min at 37 °C. Then variable amounts of the testing compounds were added and a total 10 μL of reaction mixture was continued for an additional incubation for 30 min at 37 °C. The reaction was terminated by the addition of 3 μL of 7 mM EDTA. Reaction products were analyzed on 1% agarose gel at 15 V for 15 h with a TAE running buffer. Gels were stained for 30 min in an aqueous solution of ethidium bromide (0.5 μg/mL). DNA bands were visualized by transillumination with UV light, and supercoiled DNA was quantitated using AlphaImager (Alpha Innotech Corporation). m-AMSA was used as a positive control.

    ATPase Assay

    The DNA-dependent ATPase activity of human topo IIα was monitored using a slight modification of the method reported elsewhere with a malachite green phosphate assay kit (Gentaur, Belgium).(49) Human topo IIα, 0.1 unit, and supercoiled pUC18, 3.4 nM, were incubated in a reaction buffer containing 10 mM Tris-Cl (pH 7.5), 175 mM KCl, 0.1 mM EDTA, 5 mM MgCl2, 2 mM DTT, and 2.5% glycerol at 37 °C for 30 min in the presence or absence of 400 μM compounds or novobiocin. The reaction was initiated by adding 400 μM ATP (Sigma, USA) and incubated for 30 min at 37 °C. The volume of the reaction solution after the addition of ATP was 80 μL. The 20 μL of reagent A and B in a ratio of 100:1, which was provided by the malachite green phosphate assay kit, was added to the reaction solution. The reaction solution was read at 620 nm using a VERSAmax microplate reader (Molecular Devices, USA). The OD value was determined by the amount of inorganic phosphate complexed with the malachite green and acidic molybdate. The inorganic phosphate is the product released from ATP hydrolysis performed by human topo IIα. The blank OD value was <0.1 showing that no inorganic phosphate existed before ATP hydrolysis. The % inhibition of ATP hydrolysis was calculated by setting the control without the compound as 0% inhibition. Novobiocin was used as the positive control.

    Comet Assay

    To evaluate DNA damage, the comet assay was performed using single-cell gel electrophoresis with a Trevigen kit (Gaithersburg, MD) according to the method previously reported.(36, 50) Briefly, MCF7 and T47D cells (1 × 105 cells per well) were plated in six-well plates, incubated for 24 h, and treated with 10 μM 8, 22, or etoposide for 12 and 24 h, respectively. Cells were harvested by trypsinization and resuspended in ice-cold PBS. Then cells (1 × 105) were mixed with 80 μL of low-melting agarose at 37 °C, spread on slides, and solidified in the dark for 40 min at 4 °C. Slides were lysed in ice-cold lysis solution in the dark for 30 min at 4 °C and then submerged in a fresh alkaline solution (pH > 13) at room temperature for 20 min to allow alkaline unwinding. Electrophoresis was performed under alkaline conditions for 15–30 min at 1 V/cm. Slides were rinsed twice with distilled water, once with 70% ethanol and stained with SYBR Green (Trevigen, Gaithersburg) in a TE buffer for 5 min in the dark at 4 °C. Comet images were obtained using an inverted fluorescence microscope (Zeiss, Axiovert 200) at 10× magnification, and percent DNA tail was analyzed by Comet Assay IV software (Perceptive Instruments Ltd., U.K.). Data were represented by imaging and graphically by randomly selecting comet lengths of MCF7 and T47D cells.

    Cell Cycle Analysis

    T47D cells were seeded in 60 mm dishes at a density of 5 × 105 cells per dish. When the cells reached a confluence of 80%, the cells were treated with the compounds in the concentration indicated in figure legends. Then cells were washed with ice-cold PBS (pH 7.4) and harvested with centrifugation at 2000 rpm for 5 min. The cell pellet was fixed with 70% ethanol. Fixed cells were washed with PBS before incubation with 50 μg/mL propidium iodide (Sigma, USA) and 2.5 μg/mL RNase (Sigma, USA). Fluorescence was measured on fluorescence-activated cell sorting (FACS) caliber flow cytometer (BD Biosciences, USA). At least 10 000 cells were measured for each sample.

    Annexin V/Propodium Iodide Apoptosis Detection

    Apoptotic cell death induced by compound 8 or 22 was quantified by flow cytometry using the annexin V-FITC kit (BD Pharmingen, USA) in according with the manufacturer’s protocol. Briefly, cells were seeded to a six-well plate in a density of 1 × 104 per well and incubated with or without the indicated concentration of compound 8 or 22 for 24 h. Floating cells as well as residual attached cells were collected and washed twice with PBS. The cell pellets were resuspended in 100 μL of 1× binding buffer at a concentration of 1 × 105 cells/mL. The 5 μL of annexin V-fluorescein isothiocyanate (FITC) and 10 μL of PI were added to the cell suspension. After incubation for 15 min at room temperature, stained samples were examined using a FACSCaliber flow cytometer (BD Biosciences, USA). Analysis was performed by the BD Cell Quest Pro software supplied in the instrument.

    Western Blot Analysis

    The cells were seeded in 60 mm dishes at a density of 5 × 105 cells per dish and incubated until the cells reached a confluence of 80%. The cells were then washed with FBS-free medium and incubated for 4 h in FBS-free medium followed by treating the compounds at concentrations indicated in the figure legends. The cells were washed with ice-cold phosphate buffered saline (PBS), detached with 0.25% trypsin–1 mM EDTA, and harvested by centrifugation at 2000 rpm for 3 min. The cell pellet was suspended in lysis buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl solution (pH 8.0) containing 150 mM NaCl, 0.1% SDS, 0.5% sodium deoxycholate, 1% NP-40, 100 μg/mL phenylmethanesulfonyl fluoride (PMSF), and 1% protease inhibitor cocktail) on ice for 20 min, and then the cell lysates were centrifuged at 14 000 rpm at 4 °C for 20 min. The supernatant was kept at −20 °C until needed. The total protein amount was measured using a BCA protein assay kit (Pierce, USA) to normalize untreated (control) and treated cell lysates for each compound. The same amount of each normalized sample underwent electrophoresis on a 12% SDS polyacrylamide gel, which was then transferred to a polyvinylidene difluoride (PVDF) transfer membrane (Miillipore, USA) at 150 mA for 90 min. The membrane was blocked with 5% skim milk in PBS containing 0.05% Tween 20 (TBST) for 1 h, followed by washing three times with TBST. The membrane was then incubated overnight with primary antibody at a ratio of 1:1000 at 4 °C. The membrane was washed in triplicate with TBST and incubated with secondary antibody at a ratio of 1:2000 for 1 h at room temperature, followed by washing in triplicate with TBST. PowerOpti-ECL (enhanced chemiluminescence, Animal Genetics Inc., Korea) Western blotting detection reagent was added to the membrane, which was then measured using LAS-3000 (Fuji Photo Film Co., Ltd., Japan). Primary antibodies of caspase-3, PARP, and α-tubulin and secondary antibody of Anti-IgG were purchased from Cell Signaling Technology Inc. (USA).

    Tumor Xenografts in Nude Mice

    Single-cell suspensions (5 × 106 cells) of HCT15 with ∼95% viability were injected subcutaneously into the hind legs of 5-week-old BALB/c-nu/nu nude mice (SLC Inc., Hamamatsu, Japan). An amount of 100 μL was injected in each mouse to avoid leakage, and a different site was used for each injection. When tumors reached a volume of 150–250 mm3, mice were randomly grouped as four mice per group. Compounds 8 and 22 dissolved in 50% Matrigel in serum free media and administrated once intravenously in a volume of 50 μL (20 mg/kg in final amount) at various sites around where the tumor grew. All protocols involved in tumor xenograft studies were approved by the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC) at the Research Institute of the National Cancer Center. After compound treatment, tumor volume was determined according to the formula (L × l2)/2, by measuring tumor length (L) and width (l) with a caliper. Mice were sacrificed 1 day after the final measurement. Tumors were then excised to calculate the weight, and 1/2 were frozon and 1/2 were fixed 10% NBF to make paraffin block section for H&E stain and immunohistochemistry. Ki-67 antibodies (Abcam, Cambridge, U.K.) were incubated with automatic immunohistochemical staining instrument (Ventana, Tucson, AZ) according to the manufacturer’s protocols.

    Metabolic Stability Assay of Compounds in Human, Dog, Rat, and Mouse Liver Microsomes and Pharmacokinetic Studies of Compounds in Rat Plasma

    Liquid Chromatographic and Mass Spectrometric Conditions

    HPLC instrument, consisting of an Agilent 1100 pump, an autosampler, an online degasser, and a column heater, was equipped with a reversed-phase C18 column (1.2 mm × 50 mm, 3 μm, Thermo Scientific, USA) as a stationary phase for the separation of compounds 8 and 22 and their methylated compounds 8-M and 22-M. The mobile phase comprised 10 mM ammonium formic acid–acetonitrile (10:90, v/v) with at flow rate of 0.3 mL/min. An amount of 5 μL of each sample was injected onto the HPLC column kept at 40 °C during analysis, and the eluent was directed into the mass spectrometer. LC–MS–MS analysis was performed by using an API 4000 Q trap mass spectrometer (Applied Biosystems, USA) equipped with a turbo electrospray interface in positive ionization mode. Typical product ion spectra for compounds are as follows: compound 8, m/z 338.1; compound 22, m/z 352.1; compound 8-M, m/z 352.2; compound 22-M, m/z 366.2. Multiple reaction monitoring (MRM) mode, scanning m/z 338.1 → 310.1 (compound 8), m/z 352.1 → 324.1 (compound 22), m/z 352.2 → 309.1 (compound 8-M), and m/z 366.2 → 323.1 (compound 22-M), was used to obtain the most sensitive signals. Data acquisition and quantitative processing were accomplished by using Analyst software, version 1.4.

    Sample Preparation

    The stock solution of each compound was prepared in acetonitrile and diluted with acetonitrile to yield serial working standard solutions (6.25, 12.5, 25, 50, 100, 200, 400, and 8000 ng/mL). Imipramine (100 ng/mL) was daily dissolved in acetonitrile as the internal standard. All solutions were stored at −20 °C. Rat plasma calibration standards of each compound (0, 10, 100, 1000, 10000 nM) were prepared by spiking appropriate amounts of the working standard solution into drug-free rat plasma. Quality control (QC) samples at 1, 10, 100, and 800 nM were prepared using the sample preparation method. An amount of 50 μL of each of rat plasma samples and standard solutions was added to 10 μL of IS solution. The mixture was vortexed for 1 min, and 1 mL of ethyl acetate was added. After additional vortexing for 5 min, the extract was centrifuged at 13 000 rpm for 5 min. A 900 μL aliquot of the organic layer was transferred to new Eppendorf tube and then dried by centrifugal evaporation (EYELA, Japan) at 40 °C. The residue was dissolved in 100 μL of mobile phase, vortexed for 5 min, and centrifuged at 13 000 rpm for 5 min. A 3 μL of clear aliquot from each tube was injected into the LC–MS–MS system. The calibration curves were constructed with the ratio of compound peak area to IS peak area for the y-axis and the concentration of compound for the x-axis.

    Metabolic Stability Assay

    Each compound was incubated with human, dog, rat, and mouse microsomes, respectively, in 0.4 mL of 0.1 M phosphate buffer (pH 7.4) at 37 °C for a given time (5, 15, 30, 45, or 60 min) with addition of NADPH-regenerating buffer (1.3 mM β-NADP, 3.3 mM d-glucose 6-phosphate, 3.3 mM MgCl2, and 0.4 U/mL glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase). The reaction was terminated by adding 40 μL of ice-cold IS solution and 150 μL of ice-cold acetonitrile. The extraction and preparation of sample followed the rat plasma sample preparation method. The % remaining amount of each compound was analyzed by LC–MS–MS system and was plotted versus incubation time. The half-life (t1/2) of compound was calculated by regression analysis of semilogarithmic plots.

    Application to PK Study

    The validated LC–MS–MS method was applied to a PK study following the oral administration of compounds 8, 22, 8-M, and 22-M to rats.

    Statistical Analysis

    All data are expressed as the mean ± standard deviation, with each experiment performed in triplicate. Comparison of the differences was conducted with analysis of variance (ANOVA) using the Prism statistical software package (GraphPad Software, USA). The differences were considered statistically significant when the p value was <0.05.

    Supporting Information

This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
